The **Xbox 360** is a [home video game console](/wiki/Home_video_game_console
"Home video game console") developed by [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft
"Microsoft"). As the successor to the [original Xbox](/wiki/Xbox_\(console\)
"Xbox \(console\)"), it is the second console in the [Xbox](/wiki/Xbox "Xbox")
series. It competed with [Sony](/wiki/Sony "Sony")'s [PlayStation
3](/wiki/PlayStation_3 "PlayStation 3") and [Nintendo](/wiki/Nintendo
"Nintendo")'s [Wii](/wiki/Wii "Wii") as part of the [seventh generation of
video game consoles](/wiki/Seventh_generation_of_video_game_consoles "Seventh
generation of video game consoles"). It was officially unveiled on
[MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV") on May 12, 2005, with detailed launch and game
information announced later that month at the 2005
[E3](/wiki/Electronic_Entertainment_Expo "Electronic Entertainment Expo")
expo.

The Xbox 360 features an online service, [Xbox Live](/wiki/Xbox_Live "Xbox
Live"), which was expanded from its previous iteration on the original Xbox
and received regular updates during the console's lifetime. Available in free
and subscription-based varieties, Xbox Live allows users to: [play games
online](/wiki/Online_game "Online game"); download games (through [Xbox Live
Arcade](/wiki/Xbox_Live_Arcade "Xbox Live Arcade")) and game demos; purchase
and [stream](/wiki/Streaming_media "Streaming media") music, television
programs, and films through the [Xbox Music](/wiki/Xbox_Music "Xbox Music")
and [Xbox Video](/wiki/Xbox_Video "Xbox Video") portals; and access third-
party content services through media streaming applications. In addition to
online multimedia features, it allows users to stream media from local PCs.
Several peripherals have been released, including wireless
[controllers](/wiki/Xbox_360_controller "Xbox 360 controller"), expanded [hard
drive](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard disk drive") storage, and the
[Kinect](/wiki/Kinect "Kinect") [motion sensing](/wiki/Motion_sensing "Motion
sensing") camera. The release of these additional services and peripherals
helped the Xbox brand grow from gaming-only to encompassing all multimedia,
turning it into a hub for living-room computing
entertainment.[16][17][18][19][20]

[Launched](/wiki/Xbox_360_launch "Xbox 360 launch") worldwide across
2005–2006, the Xbox 360 was initially in short supply in many regions,
including North America and Europe. The earliest versions of the console
suffered from a high [failure rate](/wiki/Failure_rate "Failure rate"),
indicated by the so-called "[Red Ring of
Death](/wiki/Xbox_360_technical_problems "Xbox 360 technical problems")",
necessitating an extension of the device's warranty period. Microsoft released
two redesigned models of the console: the _Xbox 360 S_ in 2010,[21] and the
_Xbox 360 E_ in 2013.[22] As of June 2014, 84 million Xbox 360 consoles have
been sold worldwide, making it the [sixth-highest-selling video game console
in history](/wiki/List_of_million-selling_game_consoles "List of million-
selling game consoles"), and the highest-selling console made by an American
company. Although not the best-selling console of its generation, the Xbox 360
was deemed by [TechRadar](/wiki/TechRadar "TechRadar") to be the most
influential through its emphasis on digital media distribution and multiplayer
gaming on Xbox Live.[20][23]

The Xbox 360's successor, the [Xbox One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One"), was
released on November 22, 2013.[24] On April 20, 2016, Microsoft announced that
it would end the production of new Xbox 360 hardware, although the company
will continue to support the platform.[6]

## History

### Development

Known during development as Xbox Next, Xenon, Xbox 2, Xbox FS or NextBox,[25]
the Xbox 360 was conceived in early 2003.[26] In February 2003, planning for
the Xenon [software platform](/wiki/Computing_platform "Computing platform")
began, and was headed by Microsoft's Vice President [J Allard](/wiki/J_Allard
"J Allard").[26] That month, Microsoft held an event for 400 developers in
[Bellevue, Washington](/wiki/Bellevue,_Washington "Bellevue, Washington") to
recruit support for the system.[26] Also that month, [Peter
Moore](/wiki/Peter_Moore_\(business\) "Peter Moore \(business\)"), former
president of [Sega](/wiki/Sega "Sega") of America, joined Microsoft. On August
12, 2003, ATI signed on to produce the graphic processing unit for the new
console, a deal which was publicly announced two days later.[27] Before the
launch of the Xbox 360, several [Alpha](/wiki/Alpha_test "Alpha test")
development kits were spotted using [Apple's](/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.")
[Power Mac G5](/wiki/Power_Mac_G5 "Power Mac G5") hardware. This was because
the system's [PowerPC 970](/wiki/PowerPC_970 "PowerPC 970") processor running
the same [PowerPC](/wiki/PowerPC "PowerPC") architecture that the Xbox 360
would eventually run under [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM")'s
[Xenon](/wiki/Xenon_\(processor\) "Xenon \(processor\)") processor. The cores
of the Xenon [processor](/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central processing
unit") were developed using a slightly modified version of the [PlayStation
3](/wiki/PlayStation_3 "PlayStation 3")'s [Cell
Processor](/wiki/Cell_\(microprocessor\) "Cell \(microprocessor\)") PPE
architecture. According to David Shippy and Mickie Phipps, the [IBM](/wiki/IBM
"IBM") employees were "hiding" their work from Sony and Toshiba, IBM's
partners in developing the [Cell Processor](/wiki/Cell_\(microprocessor\)
"Cell \(microprocessor\)").[28] [Jeff Minter](/wiki/Jeff_Minter "Jeff Minter")
created the [music visualization](/wiki/Music_visualization "Music
visualization") program [Neon](/wiki/Neon_\(light_synthesizer\) "Neon \(light
synthesizer\)") which is included with the Xbox 360.[29]

### Launch

Main article: [Xbox 360 launch](/wiki/Xbox_360_launch "Xbox 360 launch")

The Xbox 360 was released on November 22, 2005, in the United States and
Canada;[5] December 2, 2005, in Europe and December 10, 2005, in Japan. It was
later launched in Mexico, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Hong Kong, Singapore, South
Korea, Taiwan, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, India, and Russia. In its
first year on the market, the system launched in 36 countries, more countries
than any other console has launched in a single year.[30]

### Critical reception

In 2009, [IGN](/wiki/IGN "IGN") named the Xbox 360 the sixth-greatest video
game console of all time, out of a field of 25.[31] Although not the best-
selling console of the seventh-generation, the Xbox 360 was deemed by
[TechRadar](/wiki/TechRadar "TechRadar") to be the most influential, by
emphasizing digital media distribution and online gaming through Xbox Live,
and by popularizing [game achievement
awards](/wiki/Achievement_\(video_gaming\) "Achievement \(video
gaming\)").[20] _PC Magazine_ considered the Xbox 360 the prototype for online
gaming as it "proved that online gaming communities could thrive in the
console space".[16] Five years after the Xbox 360's original debut, the well-
received [Kinect](/wiki/Kinect "Kinect") motion capture camera was released,
which set the record of being the fastest selling consumer electronic device
in history, and extended the life of the console.[32]
_[Edge](/wiki/Edge_\(magazine\) "Edge \(magazine\)")_ ranked Xbox 360 the
second-best console of the 1993–2013 period, stating "It had its own social
network, cross-game chat, new indie games every week, and the best version of
just about every multiformat game..._[Killzone](/wiki/Killzone_\(series\)
"Killzone \(series\)")_ is no _[Halo](/wiki/Halo_\(series\) "Halo
\(series\)")_ and nowadays _[Gran Turismo](/wiki/Gran_Turismo_\(series\) "Gran
Turismo \(series\)")_ is no _[Forza](/wiki/Forza_Motorsport_\(series\) "Forza
Motorsport \(series\)")_ , but it's not about the exclusives—there's nothing
to trump [Naughty Dog](/wiki/Naughty_Dog "Naughty Dog")'s PS3 output, after
all. Rather, it's about the choices Microsoft made back in the original Xbox's
lifetime. The PC-like architecture meant the early EA Sports games ran at
60fps compared to only 30 on PS3, Xbox Live meant every dedicated player had
an existing friends list, and _Halo_ meant Microsoft had the killer next-
generation exclusive. And when developers demo games on PC now they do it with
a 360 pad—another industry benchmark, and a critical one."[33]

Xbox 360 Premium package.

The Xbox 360 began production only 69 days before launch,[39][40] and
Microsoft was not able to supply enough systems to meet initial consumer
demand in Europe or North America, selling out completely [upon
release](/wiki/Xbox_360_launch "Xbox 360 launch") in all regions except in
Japan.[41][42][43][44] Forty thousand units were offered for sale on auction
site [eBay](/wiki/EBay "EBay") during the initial week of release, 10% of the
total supply.[45] By year's end, Microsoft had shipped 1.5 million units,
including 900,000 in North America, 500,000 in Europe, and 100,000 in
Japan.[46]

In May 2008 Microsoft announced that 10 million Xbox 360s had been sold and
that it was the "first current generation gaming console" to surpass the 10
million figure in the US.[47] In the US, the Xbox 360 was the leader in
current-generation home console sales until June 2008, when it was surpassed
by the Wii.[48][49][50] The Xbox 360 has sold a total of 870,000 units in
Canada as of August 1, 2008.[51] Between January 2011 and October 2013, the
Xbox 360 was the best-selling console in the United States for these 32
consecutive months.[52]

In Europe, the Xbox 360 has sold seven million units as of November 20, 2008,
according to Microsoft.[53] In the United Kingdom, the Xbox 360 has sold 3.9
million units as of June 27, 2009, according to [GfK](/wiki/GfK "GfK") [Chart-
Track](/wiki/Chart-Track "Chart-Track").[35]

While the original [Xbox](/wiki/Xbox_\(console\) "Xbox \(console\)") sold
poorly in Japan, selling just 450,000 by November 2011[54], the Xbox 360 sold
almost as poorly, selling only 1.5 million units from 2005 to 2011.[36]
_[Edge](/wiki/Edge_\(magazine\) "Edge \(magazine\)")_ magazine reported in
August 2011 that initially lackluster and subsequently falling sales in Japan,
where Microsoft had been unable to make serious inroads into the dominance of
domestic rivals Sony and Nintendo, had led to retailers scaling down and in
some cases discontinuing sales of the Xbox 360 completely.[55] The
significance of Japan's poor sales might be overstated in the media in
comparison to overall international sales.[56]

### Legacy

The Xbox 360 sold much better than its predecessor, and although not the best-
selling console of the seventh generation, it is regarded as a success since
it strengthened Microsoft as a major force in the console market at the
expense of well-established rivals.[23] The inexpensive [Nintendo
Wii](/wiki/Nintendo_Wii "Nintendo Wii") did sell the most console units but
eventually saw a collapse of third-party software support in its later years,
and it has been viewed by some as a fad since the succeeding [Wii
U](/wiki/Wii_U "Wii U") had a poor debut in 2012.[20][57][58][59][60][61] The
[PlayStation 3](/wiki/PlayStation_3 "PlayStation 3") struggled for a time due
to being too expensive and initially lacking quality games,[62] making it far
less dominant than its predecessor, the [PlayStation 2](/wiki/PlayStation_2
"PlayStation 2"), and it took until late in the PlayStation 3's lifespan for
its sales and games to reach parity with the Xbox 360. _TechRadar_ proclaimed
that "Xbox 360 passes the baton as the king of the hill – a position that puts
all the more pressure on its successor, Xbox One".[20]

The Xbox 360's advantage over its competitors was due to the release of high-
profile games from both first party and third party developers. The 2007 [Game
Critics Awards](/wiki/Game_Critics_Awards "Game Critics Awards") honored the
platform with 38 nominations and 12 wins – more than any other
platform.[63][64] By March 2008, the Xbox 360 had reached a software [attach
rate](/wiki/Attach_rate "Attach rate") of 7.5 games per console in the US; the
rate was 7.0 in Europe, while its competitors were 3.8 (PS3) and 3.5 (Wii),
according to Microsoft.[65] At the 2008 [Game Developers
Conference](/wiki/Game_Developers_Conference "Game Developers Conference"),
Microsoft announced that it expected over 1,000 games available for Xbox 360
by the end of the year.[66] As well as enjoying exclusives such as additions
to the Halo franchise and _[Gears of War](/wiki/Gears_of_War "Gears of War")_
, the Xbox 360 has managed to gain a simultaneous release of games that were
initially planned to be PS3 exclusives, including _[Devil May Cry
4](/wiki/Devil_May_Cry_4 "Devil May Cry 4")_ ,[67] _[Ace Combat
6](/wiki/Ace_Combat_6 "Ace Combat 6")_ ,[68] _[Virtua Fighter
5](/wiki/Virtua_Fighter_5 "Virtua Fighter 5")_ ,[69] _[Grand Theft Auto
IV](/wiki/Grand_Theft_Auto_IV "Grand Theft Auto IV")_ ,[70] _[Final Fantasy
XIII](/wiki/Final_Fantasy_XIII "Final Fantasy XIII")_ ,[71] _[Tekken
6](/wiki/Tekken_6 "Tekken 6")_ ,[72] _[Metal Gear Solid :
Rising](/wiki/Metal_Gear_Rising:_Revengeance "Metal Gear Rising:
Revengeance")_ ,[73] and _[L.A. Noire](/wiki/L.A._Noire "L.A. Noire")_.[74] In
addition, Xbox 360 versions of cross-platform games were generally considered
superior to their PS3 counterparts in 2006 and 2007, due in part to the
difficulties of programming for the PS3.[75]

[TechRadar](/wiki/TechRadar "TechRadar") deemed the Xbox 360 as the most
influential game system through its emphasis of digital media distribution,
Xbox Live online gaming service, and [game
achievement](/wiki/Achievement_\(video_gaming\) "Achievement \(video
gaming\)") feature.[20] During the console's lifetime, the Xbox brand has
grown from gaming-only to encompassing all multimedia, turning it into a hub
for "living-room computing environment".[17][18][19] Five years after the Xbox
360's original debut, the well-received [Kinect](/wiki/Kinect "Kinect") motion
capture camera was released, which became the fastest selling consumer
electronic device in history, and extended the life of the console.[32]

Microsoft announced the [Xbox One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One"), successor to
the Xbox 360, at [E3](/wiki/Electronic_Entertainment_Expo "Electronic
Entertainment Expo") on June 10, 2013. Although succeeded as Microsoft's main
console by the Xbox One, support from publishers for the Xbox 360 is expected
to continue until at least 2016.[76] On April 20, 2016, Microsoft announced
the end of production of new Xbox 360 hardware; the company will continue to
provide hardware and software support for the platform, as selected Xbox 360
games can be played on Xbox One.[77]

## Hardware

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Microsoft-
Xbox-360-E-wController.jpg/220px-Microsoft-
Xbox-360-E-wController.jpg)](/wiki/File:Microsoft-Xbox-360-E-wController.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Microsoft-Xbox-360-E-wController.jpg "Enlarge")

The Xbox 360 E model, announced at 2013's
[E3](/wiki/Electronic_Entertainment_Expo "Electronic Entertainment Expo"),
shares many aesthetics with the [Xbox One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One").

The main unit of the Xbox 360 itself has slight double concavity in matte
white or black. The official color of the white model is Arctic Chill. It
features a port on the top when vertical (left side when horizontal) to which
a custom-housed [hard disk drive](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard disk drive")
unit can be attached.

On the Slim and E models, the hard drive bay is on the bottom when vertical
(right side when horizontal) and requires the opening of a concealed door to
access it. (This does not void the warranty.) The Xbox 360 Slim/E [hard
drives](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard disk drive") are standard 2.5"
[SATA](/wiki/Serial_ATA "Serial ATA") laptop drives[78], but have a custom
enclosure and firmware so that the Xbox 360 can recognize it.[79]

### Technical specifications

Main article: [Xbox 360 technical
specifications](/wiki/Xbox_360_technical_specifications "Xbox 360 technical
specifications")

Various hard disk drives have been produced, including options at 20, 60, 120,
250, or 320 GB. Inside, the Xbox 360 uses the triple-core [IBM](/wiki/IBM
"IBM") designed [Xenon](/wiki/Xenon_\(processor\) "Xenon \(processor\)") as
its CPU, with each core capable of simultaneously processing two
[threads](/wiki/Thread_\(computer_science\) "Thread \(computer science\)"),
and can therefore operate on up to six threads at once.[80] [Graphics
processing](/wiki/Computer_graphics "Computer graphics") is handled by the
[ATI](/wiki/ATI_Technologies "ATI Technologies")
[Xenos](/wiki/Xenos_\(graphics_chip\) "Xenos \(graphics chip\)"), which has 10
[MB](/wiki/Megabyte "Megabyte") of [eDRAM](/wiki/EDRAM "EDRAM"). Its main
memory pool is 512 MB in size.

### Accessories

Main article: [Xbox 360 accessories](/wiki/Xbox_360_accessories "Xbox 360
accessories")

Many accessories are available for the console, including [both wired and
wireless controllers](/wiki/Xbox_360_Controller "Xbox 360 Controller"),
faceplates for customization, headsets for chatting, a
[webcam](/wiki/Xbox_Live_Vision "Xbox Live Vision") for video chatting, [dance
mats](/wiki/Dance_pad "Dance pad") and [Gamercize](/wiki/Gamercize
"Gamercize") for exercise, three sizes of [memory
units](/wiki/Xbox_360_accessories#Memory_units "Xbox 360 accessories") and
five sizes of [hard drives](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard disk drive") (20, 60,
120, 250 (initially Japan only,[81] but later also available
elsewhere[82][83]) and 320 GB), among other items, all of which are styled to
match the console.

#### Kinect

Main article: [Kinect](/wiki/Kinect "Kinect")

[![A Kinect sensor
device.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Xbox-360-Kinect-
Standalone.png/220px-Xbox-360-Kinect-
Standalone.png)](/wiki/File:Xbox-360-Kinect-Standalone.png)

[](/wiki/File:Xbox-360-Kinect-Standalone.png "Enlarge")

A [Kinect](/wiki/Kinect "Kinect") sensor device. The Xbox 360 E revision has
an Xbox logo to the left of the Xbox 360 branding.

Kinect is a "controller-free gaming and entertainment experience" for the Xbox
360. It was first announced on June 1, 2009 at the [Electronic Entertainment
Expo](/wiki/Electronic_Entertainment_Expo "Electronic Entertainment Expo"),
under the codename, _Project Natal_.[84] The add-on
[peripheral](/wiki/Peripheral "Peripheral") enables users to control and
interact with the Xbox 360 without a [game controller](/wiki/Game_controller
"Game controller") by using gestures, [spoken
commands](/wiki/Speech_recognition "Speech recognition") and presented objects
and images. The Kinect accessory is compatible with all Xbox 360 models,[85]
connecting to new models via a custom connector, and to older ones via a USB
and mains power adapter.[86] During their
[CES](/wiki/Consumer_Electronics_Show "Consumer Electronics Show") 2010
keynote speech, Robbie Bach and Microsoft CEO [Steve
Ballmer](/wiki/Steve_Ballmer "Steve Ballmer") went on to say that Kinect will
be released during the holiday period (November–January) and work with every
360 console. It was released on November 4, 2010[87]

At launch, the Xbox 360 was available in two configurations: the "Xbox 360"
package (unofficially known as the 20 GB Pro or Premium), priced at US$399 or
[GB£](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling")279.99, and the "Xbox 360 Core",
priced at US$299 and GB£209.99. The original shipment of the Xbox 360 version
included a cut-down version of the Media Remote as a promotion. The Elite
package was launched later at US$479. The "Xbox 360 Core" was replaced by the
"Xbox 360 Arcade" in October 2007[92] and a 60 GB version of the Xbox 360 Pro
was released on August 1, 2008. The Pro package was discontinued and marked
down to US$249 on August 28, 2009 to be sold until stock ran out, while the
Elite was also marked down in price to US$299.[93]

Two major hardware revisions of the Xbox 360 have succeeded the original
models; the Xbox 360 S (also referred to as the "Slim") replaced the original
"Elite" and "Arcade" models in 2010. The S model carries a smaller,
streamlined appearance with an angular case, and utilizes a redesigned
motherboard designed to alleviate the hardware and overheating issues
experienced by prior models. It also includes a proprietary port for use with
the Kinect sensor.[21][94][95] The Xbox 360 E, a further streamlined variation
of the 360 S with a two-tone rectangular case inspired by [Xbox
One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One"), was released in 2013. In addition to its
revised aesthetics, the Xbox 360 E also has one fewer USB port, no AV
connector (and thus is HDMI-only), and no longer supports
[S/PDIF](/wiki/S/PDIF "S/PDIF").[96]

### Technical problems

Main article: [Xbox 360 technical problems](/wiki/Xbox_360_technical_problems
"Xbox 360 technical problems")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Xbox360-ringofdeath.jpg/220px-
Xbox360-ringofdeath.jpg)](/wiki/File:Xbox360-ringofdeath.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Xbox360-ringofdeath.jpg "Enlarge")

Three red lights on the Xbox 360's ring indicator representing a "General
Error requiring service of the Console or Power Adapter," commonly nicknamed
the "Red Ring of Death."

The Xbox 360 (not Slim and E models) has been subject to a number of technical
problems. Since the console's release in 2005, users have reported concerns
over its reliability and [failure rate](/wiki/Failure_rate "Failure
rate").[102][103][104]

To aid customers with defective consoles, Microsoft extended the Xbox 360's
manufacturer's warranty to three years for hardware failure problems that
generate a "General Hardware Failure" error report. A "General Hardware
Failure" is recognized on all models released before the Xbox 360 S by three
quadrants of the ring around the power button flashing red. This error is
often known as the "[Red Ring of Death](/wiki/Red_Ring_of_Death "Red Ring of
Death")".[105] In April 2009 the warranty was extended to also cover failures
related to the E74 [error code](/wiki/Error_code "Error code").[106] The
warranty extension is not granted for any other types of failures that do not
generate these specific error codes.

Since these problems surfaced, Microsoft has attempted to modify the console
to improve its reliability. Modifications include a reduction in the number,
size, and placement of components, the addition of dabs of epoxy on the
corners and edges of the CPU and GPU as glue to prevent movement relative to
the board during heat expansion,[107] and a second GPU heatsink to dissipate
more heat.[108] With the release of the redesigned Xbox 360 S, the warranty
for the newer models does not include the three-year extended coverage for
"General Hardware Failures".[109] The newer Xbox 360 S and E models indicate
system overheating when the console's power button begins to flash red, unlike
previous models where the first and third quadrant of the ring would light up
red around the power button if overheating occurred. The system will then warn
the user of imminent system shutdown until the system has cooled,[110] whereas
a flashing power button that alternates between green and red is an indication
of a "General Hardware Failure" unlike older models where three of the
quadrants would light up red.[111]

360](/wiki/List_of_Xbox_games_compatible_with_Xbox_360 "List of Xbox games
compatible with Xbox 360")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Rock_of_Ages_-
_Renaissance.jpg/260px-Rock_of_Ages_-
_Renaissance.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rock_of_Ages_-_Renaissance.jpg)

_[Rock of Ages](/wiki/Rock_of_Ages_\(video_game\) "Rock of Ages \(video

The Xbox 360 launched with 14 [games](/wiki/Xbox_360_launch_title "Xbox 360
launch title") in North America and 13 in Europe. The console's best-selling
game for 2005, _[Call of Duty 2](/wiki/Call_of_Duty_2 "Call of Duty 2")_ ,
sold over a million copies.[112] Five other games sold over a million copies
in the console's first year on the market: _[Ghost Recon Advanced
Warfighter](/wiki/Tom_Clancy%27s_Ghost_Recon_Advanced_Warfighter "Tom Clancy's
Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter")_ ,[113] _[The Elder Scrolls IV:
Oblivion](/wiki/The_Elder_Scrolls_IV:_Oblivion "The Elder Scrolls IV:
Oblivion")_ ,[114] _[Dead or Alive 4](/wiki/Dead_or_Alive_4 "Dead or Alive
4")_ ,[115] _[Saints Row](/wiki/Saints_Row_\(video_game\) "Saints Row \(video
game\)")_ ,[116] and _[Gears of War](/wiki/Gears_of_War "Gears of War")_.[117]
_Gears of War_ would become the best-selling game on the console with 3
million copies in 2006,[118] before being surpassed in 2007 by _[Halo
3](/wiki/Halo_3 "Halo 3")_ with over 8 million copies.[119]

Six games were initially available in Japan, while eagerly anticipated games
such as _Dead or Alive 4_ and _[Enchanted Arms](/wiki/Enchanted_Arms
"Enchanted Arms")_ were released in the weeks following the console's
launch.[120] Games targeted specifically for the region, such as
_[Chromehounds](/wiki/Chromehounds "Chromehounds")_ , _[Ninety-Nine
Nights](/wiki/Ninety-Nine_Nights "Ninety-Nine Nights")_ , and _[Phantasy Star
Universe](/wiki/Phantasy_Star_Universe "Phantasy Star Universe")_ , were also
released in the console's first year.[121] Microsoft also had the support of
Japanese developer [Mistwalker](/wiki/Mistwalker "Mistwalker"), founded by
_[Final Fantasy](/wiki/Final_Fantasy "Final Fantasy")_ creator [Hironobu
Sakaguchi](/wiki/Hironobu_Sakaguchi "Hironobu Sakaguchi"). Mistwalker's first
game, _[Blue Dragon](/wiki/Blue_Dragon_\(video_game\) "Blue Dragon \(video
game\)")_ , was released in 2006 and had a limited-edition bundle which sold
out quickly with over 10,000 pre-orders.[122] _Blue Dragon_ is one of three
Xbox 360 games to surpass 200,000 units in Japan, along with _[Tales of
Vesperia](/wiki/Tales_of_Vesperia "Tales of Vesperia")_ and _[Star Ocean: The
Last Hope](/wiki/Star_Ocean:_The_Last_Hope "Star Ocean: The Last Hope")_.
Mistwalker's second game, _[Lost Odyssey](/wiki/Lost_Odyssey "Lost Odyssey")_
also sold over 100,000 copies.[123]

The 2007 [Game Critics Awards](/wiki/Game_Critics_Awards "Game Critics
Awards") honored the Xbox 360 platform with 38 Nominations and 11 Wins.[124]

### Interface

Main article: [Xbox 360 system software](/wiki/Xbox_360_system_software "Xbox
360 system software")

The Xbox 360's original [graphical user
interface](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user interface") was the
_Xbox 360 Dashboard_ ; a [tabbed interface](/wiki/Tab_\(GUI\) "Tab \(GUI\)")
that featured five "Blades" (formerly four blades), and was designed by
[AKQA](/wiki/AKQA "AKQA")[125] and [Audiobrain](/wiki/Audiobrain
"Audiobrain"). It could be launched automatically when the console
[booted](/wiki/Booting "Booting") without a disc in it, or when the disc tray
was ejected, but the user had the option to select what the console does if a
game is in the tray on start up, or if inserted when already on. A simplified
version of it was also accessible at any time via the Xbox Guide button on the
gamepad.[126] This simplified version showed the user's gamercard, Xbox Live
messages and friends list. It also allowed for personal and music settings, in
addition to voice or video chats, or returning to the Xbox Dashboard from the
game.

On November 19, 2008, the Xbox 360's dashboard was changed from the "Blade"
interface, to a dashboard reminiscent of that present on the Zune and Windows
Media Center, known as the "New Xbox Experience" or NXE.[127]

Since the console's release, Microsoft has released several updates for the
Dashboard software.[128][129] These updates have included adding new features
to the console, enhancing Xbox Live functionality and multimedia playback
capabilities, adding compatibility for new accessories, and fixing bugs in the
software. Such updates are mandatory for users wishing to use Xbox Live, as
access to Xbox Live is disabled until the update is performed.

#### New Xbox Experience

Further information: [Xbox Live § New Xbox
Experience](/wiki/Xbox_Live#New_Xbox_Experience "Xbox Live")

At E3 2008, at Microsoft's Show, Microsoft's Aaron Greenberg and Marc Whitten
announced the new Xbox 360 interface called the "New Xbox Experience" (NXE).
The update was intended to ease console menu navigation. Its GUI uses the
Twist UI, previously used in [Windows Media Center](/wiki/Windows_Media_Center
"Windows Media Center") and the [Zune](/wiki/Zune "Zune"). Its new Xbox Guide
retains all Dashboard functionality (including the Marketplace browser and
disk ejection) and the original "Blade" interface (although the color scheme
has been changed to match that of the NXE Dashboard).[130]

The NXE also provides many new features. Users can now install games from disc
to the hard drive to play them with reduced load time and less disc drive
noise, but each game's disc must remain in the system in order to run. A new,
built-in Community system allows the creation of digitized
[Avatars](/wiki/Avatar_\(Xbox_360\) "Avatar \(Xbox 360\)") that can be used
for multiple activities, such as sharing photos or playing
[Arcade](/wiki/Xbox_Live_Arcade "Xbox Live Arcade") games like _[1 vs.
100](/wiki/1_vs_100_\(Xbox_360\) "1 vs 100 \(Xbox 360\)")_. The update was
released on November 19, 2008.[131]

While previous system updates have been stored on internal memory, the NXE
update was the first to require a storage device—at least a 128 MB memory card
or a [hard drive](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard disk drive").[132]

Microsoft released a further update to the Xbox 360 Dashboard starting on
December 6, 2011.[133] It included a completely new user interface which
utilizes Microsoft's [Metro design language](/wiki/Metro_\(design_language\)
"Metro \(design language\)"), and added new features such as cloud storage for
game saves and profiles, live television, [Bing](/wiki/Microsoft_Bing
"Microsoft Bing") voice search,[134] access to YouTube videos and better
support for Kinect voice commands.[135]

### Multimedia

The Xbox 360 supports videos in [Windows Media
Video](/wiki/Windows_Media_Video "Windows Media Video") (WMV) format
(including [high-definition](/wiki/High-definition_television "High-definition
television") and [PlaysForSure](/wiki/Microsoft_PlaysForSure "Microsoft
PlaysForSure") videos), as well as [H.264](/wiki/H.264/MPEG-4_AVC
"H.264/MPEG-4 AVC") and [MPEG-4](/wiki/MPEG-4 "MPEG-4") media. The December
2007 dashboard update added support for the playback of [MPEG-4
ASP](/wiki/MPEG-4_Part_2 "MPEG-4 Part 2") format videos.[136] The console can
also [display pictures](/wiki/Avatar_\(computing\) "Avatar \(computing\)") and
perform slideshows of photo collections with various transition effects, and
supports audio playback, with [music player](/wiki/Digital_audio_player
"Digital audio player") controls accessible through the Xbox 360 Guide button.
Users may play back their own music while playing games or using the
dashboard, and can play music with an interactive visual synthesizer.

Music, photos and videos can be played from standard USB [mass storage
devices](/wiki/Data_storage_device "Data storage device"), Xbox 360
proprietary [storage devices](/wiki/Data_storage_device "Data storage device")
(such as memory cards or Xbox 360 hard drives), and servers or computers with
[Windows Media Center](/wiki/Windows_Media_Center "Windows Media Center") or
[Windows XP](/wiki/Windows_XP "Windows XP") with [Service
pack](/wiki/Service_pack "Service pack") 2 or higher within the local-area
network in streaming mode.[137][138] As the Xbox 360 uses a modified version
of the [UPnP](/wiki/Universal_Plug_and_Play "Universal Plug and Play") AV
protocol,[139] some alternative UPnP servers such as uShare (part of the
[GeeXboX](/wiki/GeeXboX "GeeXboX") project) and [MythTV](/wiki/MythTV
"MythTV") can also stream media to the Xbox 360, allowing for similar
functionality from non-Windows servers. This is possible with video files up
to HD-resolution and with several [codecs](/wiki/Codec "Codec") (MPEG-2,
MPEG-4, WMV) and [container formats](/wiki/Container_format_\(digital\)
"Container format \(digital\)") (WMV, MOV, TS).[140]

As of October 27, 2009,[141] UK and Ireland users are also able to access live
and on-demand streams of [Sky television](/wiki/Sky_Digital_\(UK_%26_Ireland\)
"Sky Digital \(UK & Ireland\)") programming.[142]

At the 2007, 2008, and 2009 [Consumer Electronics
Shows](/wiki/Consumer_Electronics_Show "Consumer Electronics Show"), Microsoft
had announced that [IPTV](/wiki/IPTV "IPTV") services would soon be made
available to use through the Xbox 360. In 2007, Microsoft chairman [Bill
Gates](/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates") stated that IPTV on Xbox 360 was
expected to be available to consumers by the holiday season, using the
[Microsoft TV IPTV Edition](/wiki/Microsoft_TV_IPTV_Edition "Microsoft TV IPTV
Edition") platform.[143] In 2008, Gates and president of Entertainment &
Devices [Robbie Bach](/wiki/Robert_J._Bach "Robert J. Bach") announced a
partnership with [BT](/wiki/BT_Retail "BT Retail") in the United Kingdom, in
which the [BT Vision](/wiki/BT_Vision "BT Vision") advanced TV service, using
the newer [Microsoft Mediaroom](/wiki/Microsoft_Mediaroom "Microsoft
Mediaroom") IPTV platform, would be accessible via Xbox 360, planned for the
middle of the year.[144] BT Vision's DVR-based features would not be available
on Xbox 360 due to limited hard drive capacity.[145] In 2010, while announcing
version 2.0 of Microsoft Mediaroom, Microsoft CEO [Steve
Ballmer](/wiki/Steve_Ballmer "Steve Ballmer") mentioned that AT&T's
[U-verse](/wiki/U-verse "U-verse") IPTV service would enable Xbox 360s to be
used as set-top boxes later in the year.[146] As of January 2010, IPTV on Xbox
360 has yet to be deployed beyond limited trials.

In 2012, Microsoft released the Live Event Player, allowing for events such as
video game shows, beauty pageants, award shows, concerts, news and sporting
events to be streamed on the console via Xbox Live. The first live events
streamed on Live were the 2012 [Revolver](/wiki/Revolver_\(magazine\)
"Revolver \(magazine\)") Golden Gods, Microsoft's E3 2012 media briefing and
the [Miss Teen USA 2012](/wiki/Miss_Teen_USA_2012 "Miss Teen USA 2012") beauty
pageant.

### XNA community

Main article: [Microsoft XNA](/wiki/Microsoft_XNA "Microsoft XNA")

XNA Community is a feature whereby Xbox 360 owners can receive community-
created games, made with Microsoft XNA Game Studio, from the XNA Creators
Club. The games are written, published, and distributed through a community
managed portal. XNA Community provides a channel for digital videogame
delivery over Xbox Live that can be free of royalties, publishers and
licenses.[147][148] XNA game sales, however, did not meet original
expectations.[149] though [Xbox Live Indie Games](/wiki/Xbox_Live_Indie_Games
"Xbox Live Indie Games") (XBLIG) has had some "hits."

## Services

### Xbox Live

Main article: [Xbox Live](/wiki/Xbox_Live "Xbox Live")

When the Xbox 360 was released, Microsoft's online gaming service Xbox Live
was shut down for 24 hours and underwent a major upgrade, adding a basic non-
subscription service called Xbox Live Silver (later renamed Xbox Live Free) to
its already established premium subscription-based service (which was renamed
Gold). Xbox Live Free is included with all [SKUs](/wiki/Stock-keeping_unit
"Stock-keeping unit") of the console. It allows users to create a user
profile, join on [message boards](/wiki/Internet_forum "Internet forum"), and
access Microsoft's Xbox Live Arcade and Marketplace and talk to other
members.[150][151] A Live Free account does not generally support multiplayer
gaming; however, some games that have rather limited online functions already,
(such as _[Viva Piñata](/wiki/Viva_Pi%C3%B1ata "Viva Piñata")_) or games that
feature their own subscription service (e.g. [EA Sports](/wiki/EA_Sports "EA
Sports") games) can be played with a Free account. Xbox Live also supports
voice the latter a feature possible with the Xbox Live Vision.[152]

Xbox Live Gold includes the same features as Free and includes integrated
[online game](/wiki/Online_game "Online game") playing capabilities outside of
third-party subscriptions. Microsoft has allowed previous Xbox Live
subscribers to maintain their profile information, [friends
list](/wiki/Contact_list "Contact list"), and games history when they make the
transition to Xbox Live Gold. To transfer an Xbox Live account to the new
system, users need to link a [Windows Live ID](/wiki/Windows_Live_ID "Windows
Live ID") to their gamertag on Xbox.com.[153] When users add an Xbox Live
enabled profile to their console, they are required to provide the console
with their passport account information and the last four digits of their
[credit card number](/wiki/Payment_card_number "Payment card number"), which
is used for verification purposes and billing. An Xbox Live Gold account has
an annual cost of US$59.99, [C$](/wiki/Canadian_dollar "Canadian
dollar")59.99, [NZ$](/wiki/New_Zealand_dollar "New Zealand dollar")90.00,
[GB£](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling")39.99, or €59.99. On January 5,
2011, Xbox Live had reached over 30 million subscribers.[154]

### Xbox Live Marketplace

Main article: [Xbox Live Marketplace](/wiki/Xbox_Live_Marketplace "Xbox Live
Marketplace")

The Xbox Live Marketplace is a virtual market designed for the console that
allows Xbox Live users to download purchased or promotional content. The
service offers movie and game trailers, [game demos](/wiki/Game_demo "Game
demo"), Xbox Live Arcade games and Xbox 360 Dashboard themes as well as add-on
game content (items, costumes, levels etc.). These features are available to
both Free and Gold members on Xbox Live. A hard drive or memory unit is
required to store products purchased from Xbox Live Marketplace.[155] In order
to download priced content, users are required to purchase [Microsoft
Points](/wiki/Microsoft_Points "Microsoft Points") for use as
[scrip](/wiki/Scrip "Scrip");[156] though some products (such as trailers and
demos) are free to download. Microsoft Points can be obtained through prepaid
cards in 1,600 and 4,000-point denominations. Microsoft Points can also be
purchased through Xbox Live with a credit card in 500, 1,000, 2,000 and
5,000-point denominations. Users are able to view items available to download
on the service through a PC via the [Xbox Live
Marketplace](/wiki/Xbox_Live_Marketplace "Xbox Live Marketplace")
website.[157] An estimated seventy percent of Xbox Live users have downloaded
items from the Marketplace.[158]

### Xbox Live Arcade

Main article: [Xbox Live Arcade](/wiki/Xbox_Live_Arcade "Xbox Live Arcade")

Xbox Live Arcade is an online service operated by Microsoft that is used to
distribute downloadable video games to Xbox and Xbox 360 owners. In addition
to classic [arcade games](/wiki/Arcade_game "Arcade game") such as _[Ms. Pac-
Man](/wiki/Ms._Pac-Man "Ms. Pac-Man")_ , the service offers some new original
games like _[Assault Heroes](/wiki/Assault_Heroes "Assault Heroes")_. The Xbox
Live Arcade also features games from other consoles, such as the
[PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation "PlayStation") game _[Castlevania: Symphony of
the Night](/wiki/Castlevania:_Symphony_of_the_Night "Castlevania: Symphony of
the Night")_ and [PC games](/wiki/Personal_computer_game "Personal computer
game") such as _[Zuma](/wiki/Zuma_\(video_game\) "Zuma \(video game\)")_. The
service was first launched on November 3, 2004,[159] using a DVD to load, and
offered games for about US$5 to $15. Items are purchased using Microsoft
Points, a proprietary currency used to reduce credit card transaction charges.
On November 22, 2005, Xbox Live Arcade was re-launched with the release of the
Xbox 360, in which it was now integrated with the Xbox 360's dashboard. The
games are generally aimed toward more casual gamers; examples of the more
popular games are _[Geometry Wars](/wiki/Geometry_Wars "Geometry Wars")_ ,
_[Street Fighter II' Hyper Fighting](/wiki/Street_Fighter_II "Street Fighter
II")_, and _[Uno](/wiki/Uno_\(video_game\) "Uno \(video game\)")_.[160] On
March 24, 2010, Microsoft introduced the [Game Room](/wiki/Game_Room "Game
Room") to Xbox Live. Game Room is a gaming service for Xbox 360 and Microsoft
Windows that lets players compete in classic arcade and console games in a
virtual arcade.[161]

### Movies & TV

Main article: [Microsoft Movies & TV](/wiki/Microsoft_Movies_%26_TV "Microsoft
Movies & TV")

On November 6, 2006, Microsoft announced the Xbox Video Marketplace, an
exclusive video store accessible through the console. Launched in the United
States on November 22, 2006, the first anniversary of the Xbox 360's launch,
the service allows users in the United States to download high-definition and
standard-definition television shows and movies onto an Xbox 360 console for
viewing. With the exception of short clips, content is not currently available
for streaming, and must be downloaded. Movies are also available for rental.
They expire in 14 days after download or at the end of the first 24 hours
after the movie has begun playing, whichever comes first. Television episodes
can be purchased to own, and are transferable to an unlimited number of
consoles. Downloaded files use 5.1 [surround audio](/wiki/Surround_sound
"Surround sound") and are encoded using [VC-1](/wiki/VC-1 "VC-1") for video at
720p, with a [bitrate](/wiki/Bit_rate "Bit rate") of 6.8 Mbit/s.[162]
Television content is offered from MTV, [VH1](/wiki/VH1 "VH1"), [Comedy
Central](/wiki/Comedy_Central "Comedy Central"), [Turner
Broadcasting](/wiki/Turner_Broadcasting_System "Turner Broadcasting System"),
and [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS"); and movie content is [Warner
Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros."),
[Paramount](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures"), and
[Disney](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company"), along with
other publishers.[163]

After the Spring 2007 update, the following [video codecs](/wiki/Video_codec
"Video codec") are supported:

  * H.264 video support: Up to 15 Mbit/s, Baseline, Main, and High (up to level 4.1) Profiles with [2 channel](/wiki/2channel "2channel") AAC LC and Main Profiles.
  * MPEG-4 Part 2 video support: Up to 8 Mbit/s, Simple Profile with 2 channel AAC LC and Main Profiles.

As a late addition to the December Xbox 360 update, 25 movies were added to
the European Xbox 360 video market place on the December 11, 2007 and cost 250
Microsoft points for the SD version on the movie and 380 points for the HD
version of the movie.[164] Xbox Live members in Canada featured the ability to
go on the Xbox Live Marketplace also as of December 11, 2007 with around 30
movies to be downloaded for the same amount of Microsoft Points.[165]

On May 26, 2009, Microsoft announced it would release the [Zune
HD](/wiki/Zune_HD "Zune HD") (in the fall of 2009), which was then the next
addition to the [Zune](/wiki/Zune "Zune") product range. This was of an impact
on the Xbox Live Video Store as it was also announced that the Zune Video
Marketplace and the Xbox Live Video Store will be merged to form the [Zune
Marketplace](/wiki/Zune_Marketplace "Zune Marketplace"), which will be
arriving on Xbox Live in 7 countries initially, the United Kingdom, the United
States, France, Italy, Germany, Ireland and Spain.[166] Further details were
released at the Microsoft press conference at [E3 2009](/wiki/E3_2009 "E3
2009").[167]

On October 16, 2012, Xbox Video and Xbox Music were released, replacing the
Zune Marketplace. Xbox Video is a digital video service on that offers full HD
movies and TV series for purchase or rental on Xbox 360, Windows 8, [Windows
RT](/wiki/Windows_RT "Windows RT") PCs and [tablets](/wiki/Tablet_computer
"Tablet computer"), and Windows Phones.[168]

On August 18, 2015, Microsoft rolled out an update renaming it Movies and TV
similar to the Windows 10 App.[169]

### Groove Music

Main article: [Groove Music](/wiki/Groove_Music "Groove Music")

[Xbox Music](/wiki/Xbox_Music "Xbox Music") provides 30 million music tracks
available for purchase or access through subscription. It was announced at the
[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2012](/wiki/Electronic_Entertainment_Expo_2012
"Electronic Entertainment Expo 2012") and it integrates with [Windows
8](/wiki/Windows_8 "Windows 8") and [Windows Phone](/wiki/Windows_Phone
"Windows Phone") as well.[170]

In August 2015 Microsoft rolled out an update renaming it to Groove Music
similar to the Windows 10 App.

### Xbox SmartGlass

Main article: [Xbox SmartGlass](/wiki/Xbox_SmartGlass "Xbox SmartGlass")

Xbox SmartGlass is one of the newer features that allows for integration
between the Xbox 360 console and mobile devices such as tablets and
smartphones.[171] An app is available on Android, Windows Phone 8 and iOS.
Users of the feature can view additional content to accompany the game they
are playing, or the TV shows and movies they are watching. They can also use
their mobile device as a remote to control the Xbox 360 console.[172]

## Game development

PartnerNet, the developers-only alternative [Xbox Live](/wiki/Xbox_Live "Xbox
Live") network used by developers to beta test game content downloads and
games developed for [Xbox Live Arcade](/wiki/Xbox_Live_Arcade "Xbox Live
Arcade"),[173] runs on Xbox 360 [debug](/wiki/Debugging "Debugging") kits,
which are used both by developers and by the gaming press. In a podcast
released on February 12, 2007, a developer breached the PartnerNet [non-
disclosure agreement](/wiki/Non-disclosure_agreement "Non-disclosure
agreement") (NDA) by commenting that he had found a playable version of
_[Alien Hominid](/wiki/Alien_Hominid "Alien Hominid")_ and an unplayable
version of _[Ikaruga](/wiki/Ikaruga "Ikaruga")_ on PartnerNet. A few video
game journalists, misconstruing the breach of the NDA as an invalidation of
the NDA, immediately began reporting on other games being tested via
PartnerNet, including a remake of _[Jetpac](/wiki/Jetpac "Jetpac")_.[174]
(_Alien Hominid_ for the Xbox 360 was released on February 28 of that year,
and _Ikaruga_ was released over a year later on April 9, 2008. _Jetpac_ was
released for the Xbox 360 on March 28, 2007 as _[Jetpac
Refuelled](/wiki/Jetpac_Refuelled "Jetpac Refuelled")_.) There have also been
numerous video and screenshot leaks of game footage on PartnerNet, as well as
a complete version of _[Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode
I](/wiki/Sonic_the_Hedgehog_4:_Episode_I "Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode I")_ ,
which caused for the whole PartnerNet service to be shut down overnight on
April 3, 2010.[175] In the following days, [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft
"Microsoft") reminded developers and journalists that they were in breach of
NDA by sharing information about PartnerNet content and asked websites to
remove lists of games in development that were discovered on the
service.[176]. Sega used feedback from fans about the leaked version of Sonic
the Hedgehog 4: Episode I to refine it before they eventually released
it.[177] Additionally, a pair of hackers played their modded Halo 3 games on
PartnerNet in addition to using PartnerNet to scoop up unreleased and untested
software. The duo passed their hacked Halo pics to their friends before they
were eventually caught by Bungie engineers who left a message for the hackers
on PartnerNet which read "Winners Don't Break Into PartnerNet.".[178] Other
games that were leaked in the PartnerNet fiasco include
[Shenmue](/wiki/Shenmue "Shenmue") and Shenmue 2.[179]
